p: As can be seen from Table 1, the content of crude protein and crude lipid in Indian M. oleifera seed is relatively rich, which are 40.34% and 39.12%, respectively. These are very close to those reported in the literature; however, protein is much more than that in M. oleifera leaves (28.73%) (Juhaimi, Ghafoor, Ahmed, Babiker, & Ozcan, 2017). Compared the content of crude protein and lipid with the well‐recognized peanuts (32.65% and 48.06%) and soybean (41.05% and 21.06%) (Liu & Pan, 2016; Zheng, Jin, Geng, & Yu, 2015), the crude protein content of Indian M. oleifera seed is equivalent to soybean, higher than peanut; its crude lipid content is much higher than soybeans, slightly lower than peanuts. It is reported that M. oleifera seed protein has the effect of water purification and anticoagulation (Aline et al., 2017; Luciana et al., 2013; Marichamy & Ramasamy, 2015), and M. oleifera oil can accelerate the healing of wounds (Duan et al., 2011). It shows that the Indian M. oleifera seed is not only rich in crude protein and lipid, but also has various effects. We can deeply develop its plant protein and vegetable oil, such as functional foods, feed, water purification, cosmetic raw materials, plant growth promoters, and fungicides.
